Bilaspur District

Bilaspur lies where the Shivalik hills meet the Punjab plains. Once the princely state of Kahlur, it merged with Himachal in 1954. The district is also called Satdhar Kahlur – Land of Seven Hills – with Naina Devi, Kot, Jhanjhar, Tiun, Bandla, Bahadurpur, and Ratanpur hills shaping its landscape and culture.

Our Hidden Favourites

  • Gobind Sagar Lake — 90 km long reservoir formed by Bhakra Dam, good for boating, fishing, and water sports.
  • Bandla Hill — Famous for paragliding and wide views of Bilaspur town and Gobind Sagar.
  • Bahadurpur Hill — Highest hill of the district (1,980 m), with deodar forests, a temple, and fort ruins.
  • Rukmani Kund — Small sacred pond in the hills, peaceful for a short visit.
  • Kandrour Bridge — Built in 1965, once Asia’s highest bridge (80 m above the Sutlej).

Towns & Villages

  • Bilaspur Town (HQ) – Rebuilt after old Bilaspur submerged in Gobind Sagar. Has bazaars, offices, Luhnu Ground (Nalwari fair venue), and nearby ACC Cement Factory at Barmana.
  • Ghumarwin – Bustling market town with fairs, shops, and Sutlej valley views.
  • Sri Naina Devi – Pilgrimage town at $1,100\text{ m}$, home to Shri Naina Devi Ji temple, one of 51 Shakti Peeths. Ropeway access; panoramic views.
  • Swarghat – Roadside hill stop at $1,200\text{ m}$ on the Chandigarh–Manali highway, pine forests and small temple fairs.

Culture & Festivals

  • Nalwari Fair (March):Started in 1883 as a cattle fair; now features bull trading, wrestling, folk dances, theatre, and street food.
  • Naina Devi Fair (Navratri): Tens of thousands of devotees visit the temple, with langars and processions.
  • Markanda Fair (Baisakhi): Held at Markandeya Rishi temple by the stream.
  • Local traditions: Holi faag songs, Diwali feasts, Sair harvest festival in September, Magh Sankranti dips at nearby hot springs.

Education & Youth

  • AIIMS Bilaspur (opened 2022): Major medical institute.
  • Govt. Hydro Engineering College, Bandla: Brings students and professionals from across India.
  • Youth:Youth engage in cricket (matches at Luhnu Ground), NCC, scouting, trekking, and local fairs. Many aim for govt jobs or army recruitment. Seasonal migration and work in cement/hydro projects add diversity.

Food & Markets

  • Staple foods:Wheat, barley, maize, rajma, peas, turnips, pumpkin, potato, seasonal greens. Salted tea (cha) with sattu is popular.
  • Special dishes:Siddu, babru, kadhi, rajma-chawal, chha gosht, bhey pakora. Himachali dham is served at weddings and fairs
  • Local drinks: Chulli (apricot liquor), Angoori (grape), and barley-based brews.
  • Where to eat:
    • Bahadur Dhaba (Ghagas) – Makki roti, dal, kadhi on a wood chulha.
    • Gupta Bhojanalaya (Bilaspur bus stand) – Simple rajma-chawal.
    • Saanwara Sweets (Bilaspur market) – Anjeer kalakand.
    • Ghumarwin stalls – Golgappas, bhey pakora, siddu.

Travel Basics

  • Getting there: On NH-205 (old Chandigarh–Manali road). Well connected by road from Chandigarh, Shimla, Hamirpur, and Una.
  • Transport: Regular HRTC buses, taxis in Bilaspur town and Ghumarwin.
  • Connectivity: Mobile and ATMs available in towns; BSNL and Jio work best.
  • Seasons:
    • Apr–Jun: Hot, up to 40°C in low areas.
    • Jul–Aug: Monsoon rains, landslides near Swarghat.
    • Sep–Oct: Best time, fairs and clear skies.
    • Nov–Feb: Mild in town, occasional snow at Bahadurpur.
  • Monsoon note: Jul–Sep—roads can be slippery; rafting season depends on flow.

Heritage & Sacred Sites

  • Temples & Shrines
    • Shri Naina Devi Ji – Shakti Peeth temple on a hill.
    • Baba Balak Nath Ji (Shahtalai & Deotsidh route) – Cave shrine and pilgrimage.
    • Markandeya Rishi Temple – Streamside shrine with Baisakhi fair.
    • Vyasa Gufa – Cave on Sutlej linked to Rishi Vyasa.
    • Other devta temples: Guga Gehrwin, Sidh Baba Nahar Singh (Dholra), Sohni Devi near Ghumarwin.
  • Fort Ruins
    • Kot Kahlur – 8th-century fort of Raja Bir Chand, near Naina Devi.
    • Bachhretu Fort – 14th-century ruins overlooking Gobind Sagar.
    • Sariun Fort – On Tiun range; linked to Anglo-Gorkha battles.
    • Bahadurpur Fort – Summer retreat of Bilaspur rulers; now forest ruins.
  • Submerged Bilaspur — 28 old temples of the former capital town lie underwater in Gobind Sagar. At times, their tops emerge when lake levels drop.
